awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Phage-based nanobiosensors for the rapid detection of food and waterborne pathogens
awd_abstract_narration:
Accurately detecting low levels of disease-causing bacteria in a large population of many types of (often similar but non-disease causing) bacteria is challenging, and will be addressed in this project by designing a nanobiosensor that is able to  separate low numbers of the bad bacteria from complex samples, and concentrate it into a small volume and finally detect the presence of the disease-causing bacteria.  


The proposed work consists of first generation nanobot consisting of a genetically engineered and magnetized virus (phage) which can specifically bind, separate, concentrate, and infect target bacteria in liquid samples. The phage is specific to E. coli bacteria and will be genetically engineered to produce large quantities of a reporter enzyme (phosphatase) during the 1-hour infection. Following infection, the E. coli is naturally lysed to release replicated viruses, thereby also releasing the high concentration of reporter enzyme. The engineered enzymes can then be sensitively detected using electrochemistry on a nanostructured electrode. It is proposed that phage can be utilized in combination with magnetic nanoparticles and nanostructured electrodes to promote the rapid recognition, separation, and detection in a pragmatic manner. The following research aims will be pursued: 1) Engineer the phage T4 to carry a gene for an engineered phosphatase enzyme and allow targeted attachment onto magnetic nanoparticles, 2) Use the magnetic nanoprobes to separate and concentrate E. coli from liquid samples, and 3) Electrochemically detect the phosphatase on a nanostructured electrode correlating amperometric signal to initial bacterial concentration. As part of this proposal, the PIs? research groups will develop high-definition computer-generated teaching tools which will allow students to visualize the concepts of genetic engineering and pages. The educational videos will be produced documentary-style and will include photo-realistic animations. The videos will be freely available for download via YouTube and the PI websites.

por.por_cntn:
The World Health Organization has reported that contaminated drinking water continues to be a global problem resulting in almost half a million deaths a year. This project aimed to develop methods to more rapidly detect potential contamination of food and drinking water from fecal sources. We used the natural viral predator of bacteria, the bacteriophage, to help capture and detect E. coli from drinking water samples. Bacteriophages exist naturally in the environment and while small are cumulatively estimated be the largest biomass on the planet.

While not all E. coli is harmful its origin in the intestines of animals makes it useful as an indicator that food or water has been contaminated with fecal matter. Currently, most regulatory agencies require no detectable E. coli in a 100 mL (~3.4 fl oz) sample of drinking water. Due to the high frequency of testing and the typical testing environments, these tests must be low-cost, easy-to-use, and deliver rapid results.

The selected the bacteriophage T4 which specifically targets E. coli for our project. In nature, phages such as T4 will identify and bind to their host bacteria before injecting their DNA into the E. coli cell. This triggers an infection in the bacteria resulting in expression of the bacteriophage genes and results in replication of the bacteriophage. At the end of the infection, the bacteria are burst open releasing approximately 100 newly replicated bacteriophages.

We utilized T4 to allow us to detect the presence of E. coli in a water sample by genetically engineering the bacteriophage with two modifications. 1) We inserted a luciferase gene into the bacteriophage genome. This gene originates from deep sea shrimp and results in the emission of light when expressed. The luciferase is expressed during the infection of E. coli and therefore the emission of light serves as an indicator of the presence of E. coli. 2) We genetically engineered T4 to allow it to be attached to magnetic nanoparticles. This allows us to put the bacteriophages into larger samples (100 mL) where they will bind the E. coli before we place a magnet in proximity of the sample. The result is the magnetic bacteriophages pulling the attached E. coli into a concentrated sample prior to detection.

As a result, our sensor was able to detect less than ten E. coli in a 100 mL sample. Due to the difficulty of preparing a sample with a single bacterium, it is unknown if that would be detectable. The test requires approximately 25% of the time required for current tests, is low cost, and relatively easy to use. The assay can be engineered to target any bacteria for which there are known bacteriophages. This includes other foodborne pathogens such as Salmonella and Listeria, or more medically important bacteria such as S. aureus and Pseudomonas.

During the project, we have also built digital twins of bacteriophages for use in 3D animations. These images were constructed from electron microscopy image (cryo-EM) data and are therefore structurally accurate. These animations will be uploaded to the public domain such as YouTube and are intended for educational use. The animations describe what phages are and how they can be useful as tools when combating bacteria.
